Title:
Phylogenetic distribution and evolution of secondary
metabolites in the lichenized fungal genus Lepraria (Lecanorales:
Stereocaulaceae)
Abstract:
Molecular sequence data are used to explore the
phylogenetic distribution of secondary metabolites and metabolite
classes among species of Lepraria. All substance classes examined were
phylogenetically widespread, except for ß-orcinol meta-depsides and
anthraquinones, which appeared rare and restricted to a single major
clade. Benzyl esters were also found to be rare. Taxa producing each
substance class examined were not monophyletic. The ability to regularly
produce orcinol para-depsides, ß-orcinol meta-depsides, ß-orcinol
depsidones, dibenzofurans, benzyl esters, terpenoids and anthraquinones
appears to have been gained more than lost, while the ability to produce
ß-orcinol para-depsides and higher aliphatic acids has been lost more
than gained. Our results suggest that chemical similarities may not
necessarily indicate close phylogenetic relationships. Finally,
ancestral state reconstruction at the base of genus Lepraria suggests
that its ancestor produced ß-orcinol para-depsides (atranorin) but did
not produce orcinol para-depsides, ß-orcinol meta-depsides, benzyl
esters or anthraquinones.
